https://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/c.Description: The SEDAC Hazards Mapper enables users to visualize data and map layers related to Socioeconomic, Infrastructure, Natural Disasters, and Environment and analyze potential impacts and exposure. The web app mashes up layers from various sources, including SEDAC, NASA LANCE, NASA GIBS, USGS, NOAA, ESRI, and others. The population count data for 2015 can be visualized as a map layer in the Hazards Mapper. The population estimates are obtained using SEDAC Population Estimation Service (PES), which is an OGC compliant Web Processing Service (WPS).

https://doi.org/10.7927/H40P0WXQ.Description: The Global Cyclone Total Economic Loss Risk Deciles dataset provides a spatial surface of the total economic impacts of global cyclone hazard. The dataset is a 2.5 minute grid of global cyclone total economic loss risks.

https://doi.org/10.7927/H4XS5S9Q.Description: The Global Flood Proportional Economic Loss Risk Deciles dataset provides a spatial surface of the proportional economic impacts of global flood hazard. The dataset is a 2.5 minute grid of flood hazard economic loss as proportions of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per analytical unit. Estimates of GDP at risk are based on regional economic loss rates derived from historical records of the Emergency Events Database (EM-DAT).

https://doi.org/10.7927/H4T151KP.Description: The Global Flood Total Economic Loss Risk Deciles dataset provides a spatial surface of the total economic impacts of global flood hazard. The dataset is a 2.5 minute grid of global flood total economic loss risks.

https://doi.org/10.7927/H4WS8R5B.Description: The Global Multihazard Proportional Economic Loss Risk Deciles dataset shows areas of the world at greater risk of multihazard-based economic loss. The dataset is a 2.5-minute grid of multihazard-based economic loss risk as a proportion of the economic productivity of the grid cell. The dataset does not show a multihazard index, but rather combinations of hazard risk categories (drought, seismic, and hydro).

https://doi.org/10.7927/H4S180F9.Description: The Global Multihazard Total Economic Loss Risk Deciles dataset shows areas of the world at greater risk of multihazard total economic loss. These data can aid in natural disaster research and preparedness.

https://doi.org/10.7927/zz3b-8y61.Description: The Geocoded Disasters (GDIS) Dataset is a geocoded extension of a selection of natural disasters from the Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters (CRED) Emergency Events Database (EMDAT). The dataset encompasses 39,953 locations for 9,924 disasters that occurred worldwide in the years 1960 to 2018.

https://doi.org/10.7927/H4668B3D.Description: The Global Flood Hazard Frequency and Distribution dataset was developed by the Columbia University Center for Hazards and Risk Research and the Columbia University Center for International Earth Science Information Network. It provides a means of assessing the relative distribution and frequency of global flood hazard.

https://doi.org/10.7927/6s2a-9r49.Description: The US Social Vulnerability Index Grids dataset contains gridded layers for the overall Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Social Vulnerability Index (SVI) using four subcategory themes: Socioeconomic, Household Composition & Disability, Minority Status & Language, and Housing Type & Transportation based on census tract level inputs from 15 variables for the years 2000, 2010, 2014, 2016, and 2018. SVI values range between 0 and 1 based on their percentile position among all census tracts in the US, with 0 representing lowest vulnerability census tracts and 1 representing highest vulnerability census tracts.

https://dx.doi.org/10.7927/9ryj-6467.Description: The VIIRS Plus DMSP Change in Lights (VIIRS+DMSP dLIGHT) dataset shows changes in brightness and extent of global nighttime lights networks over two decades. These data may be useful in urban heat research.

https://dx.doi.org/10.7927/d1x1-d702.Description: The Low Elevation Coastal Zone (LECZ) Urban-Rural Population and Land Area Estimates, v3 data set contains land areas with urban, quasi-urban, rural, and total populations counts within the LECZ for 234 countries and other recognized territories for the years 1990, 2000, and 2015.
https://dx.doi.org/10.7927/d1x1-d702.Project: Urban-Rural Population and Land Area Estimates

https://doi.org/10.7927/d1x1-d702.Description: The Low Elevation Coastal Zone (LECZ) Urban-Rural Population and Land Area Estimates, v3 data set contains land areas with urban, quasi-urban, rural, and total populations counts within the LECZ for 234 countries and other recognized territories for the years 1990, 2000, and 2015.
https://doi.org/10.7927/d1x1-d702.Project: Urban-Rural Population and Land Area Estimates

https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/news/release-nas.Description: The LP DAAC is pleased to announce the availability of NASADEM data products at 1 arc-second resolution. NASADEM extends the legacy of the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) by improving the digital elevation model (DEM) height accuracy and data coverage, as well as providing additional SRTM radar-related data products. The improvements were achieved by reprocessing the original SRTM radar signal data and telemetry data with updated algorithms and auxiliary data not available at the time of the original SRTM processing.
https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/news/release-nas.Project: MEaSUREs - Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) Ancillary and DEM Products

https://dx.doi.org/10.3334/ORNLDAAC/1564.Description: The ABoVE Landsat-derived Burn Scar dNBR across Alaska and Canada, 1985-2015 dataset contains differenced Normalized Burned Ratio (dNBR) at 30m resolution calculated for burn scars from fires that occurred within the Arctic-Boreal Vulnerability Experiment (ABoVE) Project domain in Alaska and Canada during 1985-2015. These data may be useful in research related to fire ecology, natural hazards, and human dimensions.

https://dx.doi.org/10.3334/ORNLDAAC/1694.Description: The ABoVE Burn Severity of Soil Organic Matter, Northwest Territories, Canada, 2014-2015 dataset provides maps at 30m resolution of landscape surface burn severity, surface litter, and soil organic layers from the 2014-2015 fires in the Northwest Territories and Northern Alberta, Canada. The maps were derived from Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager-Thermal Infrared Sensor (OLI-TIRS) imagery and two separate multiple linear regression models trained with field data, one for the Plains and a second for the Shield ecoregion. Field observations were used to estimate area burned in each of five severity classes: unburned, singed, light, moderate, and severely burned.
